Covalent heterogenization of discrete bis(8-quinolinolato)dioxomolybdenum(VI) and dioxotungsten(VI) complexes by a metal-template/metal-exchange method: Cyclooctene epoxidation catalysts with enhanced performances Ying Yang a ⁎ Soma Chattopadhyay b Tomohiro Shibata b Yang Ren c Sungsik Lee c Qiubin Kan d a State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Changping, Beijing 102249, PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Changping Beijing 102249 PR China b Department of Physics, Advanced Materials Group, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616, USA Department of Physics, Advanced Materials Group, Illinois Institute of Technology Chicago IL 60616 USA c X-ray Science Division, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 S. Cass Ave., Argonne, IL 60439, USA X-ray Science Division, Argonne National Laboratory 9700 S. Cass Ave. Argonne IL 60439 USA d College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130023, Jilin, PR China College of Chemistry, Jilin University Changchun Jilin 130023 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 10 89731283; fax: +86 10 89731283/+86 512 6870 2770. Graphical abstract A metal-template/metal-exchange method was used to imprint covalently attached bis(8-quinolinolato)dioxomolybdenum(VI) and dioxotungsten(VI) complexes onto large surface-area, mesoporous SBA-15 silica to obtain discrete MoO2 VIT and WO2 VIT catalysts bearing different metal loadings, respectively. Homogeneous counterparts, MoO2 VIN and WO2 VIN, as well as randomly ligand-grafted heterogeneous analogues, MoO2 VIG and WO2 VIG, were also prepared for comparison. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS), pair distribution function (PDF) and UV–vis data demonstrate that MoO2 VIT and WO2 VIT adopt a more solution-like bis(8-quinolinol) coordination environment than MoO2 VIG and WO2 VIG, respectively. Correspondingly, the templated MoVI and WVI catalysts show superior performances to their randomly grafted counterparts and neat analogues in the epoxidation of cyclooctene. It is found that the representative MoO2 VIT-10% catalyst can be recycled up to five times without significant loss of reactivity, and heterogeneity test confirms the high stability of MoO2 VIT-10% catalyst against leaching of active species into solution. The homogeneity of the discrete bis(8-quinolinol) metal spheres templated on SBA-15 should be responsible for the superior performances. Keywords Metal-template/metal-exchange 8-Quinolinol Molybdenum Tungsten SBA-15 Cyclooctene epoxidation 1 Introduction The epoxidation of alkenes is of great interest both academically and industrially, since epoxides are key building blocks for the synthesis of both bulk and fine chemicals [1,2]. A wide range of homogeneous catalysts (TiIV, VV, CrVI, MoVI, WVI, etc.) exist for this process, among which VI B group metals bearing Lewis acid properties, like MoVI and WVI compounds, are widely concerned due to their high reactivity and epoxide selectivity [3,4]. However, homogeneous form often suffers from severe deactivation due to easy formation of dimeric peroxo- and μ-oxo species. Therefore, much attention has been devoted to covalent immobilization of olefin epoxidation catalysts onto solid supports to increase catalyst stability and to allow for catalyst recycling and product separation [5–9]. Covalent attachment of MoVI and WVI compounds onto porous materials to realize site isolation, and thus to improve their catalytic performances in olefin epoxidations, is still a hot topic these days. Nunes and coworkers randomly grafted dioxomolybdenum(VI) complex [MoO2Cl2(LL)] (L is RNC(Ph)C(Ph)NR, R=(CH2)3Si(OEt)3) onto MCM-48, and found that the supported MoVI catalyst showed enhanced cyclooctene conversion of 63% and could be recycled without significant loss of activity [10]. Similarly, the compound MoO2(acac)2 was grafted onto NS chelating Schiff base-containing MCM-41, and it proved to be highly efficient for the epoxidation of both linear and cyclicalkenes with tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) [11]. Mesoporous SBA-15 materials modified with oxodiperoxo tungsten complexes were also reported to be efficient for the epoxidation of olefins with hydrogen peroxide [12]. However, for these randomly grafted species, even at low coverage, mono-oxo, dioxo and dimeric surface species coexist to display structural diversity [10,11,13,14]. Unselective reactive sites would disproportionately contribute to selectivity and erode the selectivity of catalyst, thus making it difficult to determine structure-reactivity correlations. However, from a catalytic point view, these catalytic systems are still of special interest and can be further improved via optimization of catalyst design. Recent advances in the heterogenization of discrete catalysts focus on tethering metal complexes of single multidentate ligands such as porphyrin, salen or 1,4,7-triazacyclononane to provide the requisite metal coordination for catalytic activity via a random grafting technique [15–17]. The random grafting of such complexes onto a support ensures the retention of the homogeneous coordination sphere and the catalytic reactivity due to the possible benefit of site isolation. However, the immobilization of coordination environment for a single metal created from several independent ligands, such as bis(8-quinolinolato)dioxomolybdenum(VI) and dioxotungsten(VI), are relatively limited. The desirable covalent imprinting of coordination sites composed of several independent ligands was first achieved by Terry and Stack [18,19]. They developed a metal-template/metal-exchange method to control the distribution of covalently attached independent 1,10-phenanthroline ligands at low loadings. Using this method, they prepared covalently attached biligand coordination complex [MnII(phen)2]2+ and [FeII(phen)2], which showed an enhanced reactivity in the epoxidation of vinylcyclohexane as compared to their randomly grafted ones. Such enhancement was also observed in epoxidation of cyclooctene and styrene with TBHP, by using covalently attached bis(8-quinolinolato) oxovanadium(IV) catalyst [20]. In continuation of our research, herein we use the same metal-template/metal-exchange method to covalently attach bis(8-quinolinolato)dioxomolybdenum(VI) and dioxotungsten(VI) compounds onto large surface SBA-15 silica to control their concentration and distribution. For comparison, neat metal complexes and randomly grafted ones are also designed, fully characterized and screened as catalysts for the epoxidation of cyclooctene. The mesoporous SBA-15 material was used rather than MCM-41 and MCM-48 mainly because of its larger pore diameters and pore volumes permitting easy diffusion of bulky reactants and products in the liquid-phase epoxidations. The mesoporous structural integrity throughout the heterogenization procedure, the successful anchorage of metal complexes, and the loadings of metal and ligand as well as the local structure of active species were determined by XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption, TEM, SEM, FT-IR, UV–vis spectroscopy, 29Si MAS NMR, ICP-AES, TG/DSC, CHN elemental analysis, PDF and XAFS measurements. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The following chemicals were commercially available and were used as received: 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane (Aldrich), Pluronic P123 (EO20PO70EO20) (Aldrich), 8-quinolinol (99%), hexamethyldisiloxane, (Me3Si)2O (>99.5%), cis-cyclooctene (Aldrich), tetraethyl orthosilicate Si(OC2H5)4 (99%), TBHP (65%), HCHO (37wt%), MoO3, WCl6, ZnCl2, Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O, Et3N, CH3COOH, and all organic solvents are A.R. grade. Both toluene and tetrahydrofuran were dried by Na/diphenylketone ketyl, distilled under N2 atmosphere and stored over molecular sieves (4Å). All air or moisture-sensitive compounds were transferred using standard vacuum line and Schlenk technique. 2.2 Synthetic procedures First, the mesoporous support SBA-15 was prepared by a literature method [21] and activated by heating at 120°C for 2h and then used to prepare 8-quinolinol modified SBA-15. 5-chloromethyl-8-quinolinol hydrochloride (1C·HCl) and its zinc complex ([ZnII(1C)2]·H2O) were prepared and examined by elemental analysis, 1H NMR, FT-IR and UV–vis spectroscopy (see supporting information, Figs. S1–3). Precursor compounds, such as dichlorobis-(dimethylformamide)dioxomolybdenum(VI), MoO2Cl2(dmf)2, tungsten(VI) oxychloride, WOCl4, and dioxodichlorotungstendimethoxyethane, WO2Cl2(dme), were synthesized according to the reported procedures [22–24]. The synthetic details and characterization data are shown in Supporting Information (Figs. S4–6). The procedure for the covalent attachment of 8-quinolinol complexes of dioxo-molybdenum(VI) and dioxotungsten(VI) onto SBA-15 via random grafting and templating methods to form MO2 VIT and MO2 VIG (M=Mo or W) is depicted in Scheme 1 , respectively, and described as follows. The preparation of the neat complex MVIN is also given below. 2.2.1 Preparation of MoO2 VIT and WO2 VIT via templating method The preparation procedure for MoO2 VIT and WO2 VIT included (i) the templating graft, (ii) ZnII removal and (iii) metalation. (i) Typically, 0.225g of fully dried bis(5-chloromethyl-8-quinolinol)zinc(II) ([ZnII(1C)2] was combined with 0.18ml of 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane (3-MPTMS, 1.0mmol) in 20ml of dry THF under N2 atmosphere, and the mixture was refluxed for 15h. Then 0.938, 0.625 or 0.312g of SBA-15 was added and the mixture was stirred for another 24h. The resulting green solid was filtered in air to give ZnIIT-5%, ZnIIT-10% or ZnIIT-15% (5, 10 and 15% correspond to the molar ratios of 3-MPTMS to silica in the synthetic mixture), with a loading of 0.60, 0.78, 1.12mmolg−1 of 1 (1=5-(3-(trimethoxylsilyl)propylthio)methyl-8-quinolinol (1P) after covalent attachment to the silica surface). Approximately 56.3, 48.8 or 34.9% of 1P was immobilized onto the silica by this procedure as determined by nitrogen analysis and the ligand/zinc molar ratio was ca. 2.1:1. (ii) ZnII removal from ZnIIT was accomplished typically by refluxing 1.0g of ZnIIT with 20ml of acetic acid at 80°C for 24h and then filtering and rinsing with water. This process was repeated three times to give bis-1 templated SBA-15 with insignificant ZnII residue: T-5%, T-10%, or T-15%. (iii) To metalate T, certain amount of MoO2Cl2(dmf)2 or WO2Cl2(dme) combined with T-5%, T-10% or T-15% (0.5 equiv. MoO2 VI (WO2 VI) per 1) was stirred in CHCl3 under N2 atmosphere for 24h before filtering. To remove any weakly coordinated metal, the metalated material was Soxhlet-extracted with CH2Cl2 for 24h, filtered and washed with copious amounts of CH2Cl2 and dried in vacuum. Anal. found for MoO2 VIT-5%: C, 6.51; H, 1.69; N, 0.28; Mo, 0.92%. MoO2 VIT-10%: C, 17.28; H, 1.85; N, 0.60; Mo, 2.05%. MoO2 VIT-15%: C, 8.34; H, 1.76; N, 1.04; Mo, 3.22%. WO2 VIT-5%: C, 11.96; H, 1.69; N, 0.10; W, 0.64%. WO2 VIT-10%: C, 12.09; H, 1.72; N, 0.24; W, 1.69%. WO2 VIT-15%: C, 17.88; H, 1.98; N, 0.36; W, 2.28%. 2.2.2 Preparation of MoO2 VIG and WO2 VIG via random grafting method 0.23g of 5-chloromethyl-8-quinolinol hydrochloride (1C·HCl) combined with 0.14ml of triethylamine was mixed with 0.18ml of 3-MPTMS, and the mixture was refluxed in 20ml dry THF under N2 atmosphere for 24h. Then 0.938, 0.612 or 0.312g of SBA-15 was added and further refluxed for 24h. Filtering gave G-5%, G-10% or G-15% with a loading of 0.45, 0.68 or 0.83mmolg−1 of 1. Finally, materials MoO2 VIG and WO2 VIG were obtained by metalation procedure mentioned above. Anal. found for MoO2 VIG-5%: C, 5.92; H, 2.03; N, 0.38; Mo, 1.87%. MoO2 VIG-10%: C, 14.20; H, 1.51; N, 1.08; Mo, 4.55%. MoO2 VIG-15%: C, 8.74; H, 1.95; N, 1.25; Mo, 5.04%. WO2 VIG-5%: C, 10.50; H, 1.67; N, 0.15; W, 1.35%. WO2 VIG-10%: C, 6.48; H, 1.26; N, 0.34; W, 2.70%. WO2 VIG-15%: C, 8.37; H, 1.33; N, 0.45; W, 3.22%. 2.2.3 Preparation of neat dioxomolybdenum and dioxotungsten complexes To prepare the neat dioxomolybdenum and dioxotungsten complexes, 1.0mmol of 8-quinolinol combined with 0.5mmol of MoO2Cl2(dmf)2 or WO2Cl2(dme) was dissolved in CHCl3 under N2 atmosphere and stirred at room temperature for 24h. The solvent was removed, and the resulting solid was washed with copious CHCl3 and dried in vacuum and denoted as MoO2 VIN or WO2 VIN. Anal. found for MoO2 VIN: C, 50.89; H, 2.80; N, 6.72%. Calculated: C, 51.89; H, 2.88; N, 6.73%. Anal. found for WO2 VIN: C, 43.10; H, 2.43; N, 5.50%. Calculated: C, 42.87; H, 2.38; N, 5.56%. MoO2 VIN, FTIR (KBr pellets, cm−1): 1608 (CC), 1574, 1498 (Py), 925 (MoO), 539 (MoO), 497 (MoN) (Fig. S7i); UV–vis, λ (nm): 246, 266, 398, 636 (Fig. S8a). WO2 VIN, FTIR (KBr pellets, cm−1): 1633, 1554, 1497, 1463, 1377, 1306, 1103, 935 (WO), 822 (Fig. S7j); UV–vis, λ (nm): 258, 317, 374 (Fig. S8d). 2.3 Characterization Powder XRD was collected with a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer with nickel filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5418Å). The samples were scanned in the range 2θ =0.4–5.0° and in steps of 2°min−1. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were recorded at 77K with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Before measurements, the samples were outgassed at 120°C for 4h. The specific surface area was calculated by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the pore size distributions were measured by using Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) analyze from the adsorption branch of the isotherms. The infrared spectra (IR) of samples were recorded in KBr disks using a NICOLET impact 410 spectrometer. UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer UV–vis spectrophotometer Lambda 20 using barium sulfate as the standard in the range 200–800nm. TG/DSC analysis was carried out on NETZSCH STA 409 PC instrument from ambient temperature to 800°C under Ar atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. Liquid 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury—300MHz or Bruker Avance III 400MHz instruments using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard. The 29Si MAS NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX-400 system equipped with a magic-angle spin probe in a 4-mm ZrO2 rotor. The 29Si MAS NMR spectra were recorded at 79.4MHz, with a pulse delay of 2.0s, acquisition time of 16.9ms, and spinning rate of 4kHz. Microanalysis for C, H and N were performed at the Perkin Elmer 2400. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were obtained on a JEOL JSM-890 field emission scanning microscope with an acceleration voltage of 10kV. Samples subjected to analysis were coated with gold using a sputter coater. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was recorded on a JEOL JEM 2010 operated at 200kV. After the samples were sonicated for 5min in EtOH, one drop of the suspended sample was dripped in a holely carbon film supported on a 300mesh copper grid. Total scattering patterns (Bragg and diffuse scattering data) were collected at the high energy beamline 11-ID-C at the Advanced Photo Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory, IL, USA. A wavelength of 0.10798Ǻ (115keV) and 0.6mm×0.6mm beam size were used to obtain two-dimensional diffraction patterns in Laue geometry using a Perkin-Elmer large area detector placed at 360mm from the sample. Samples were packed into the Kapton capillaries, and the program Fit2D with a CeO2 calibration standard was used to integrate the data. Pair distribution function (PDF) patterns (G(r)) were obtained with the PDFGetX2 software and the data range used was up to 43 Ǻ−1 Q. Mo K-edge and W L 3-edge XAFS spectra for the Mo and W samples and a reference compound diluted with boron nitride which were pressed into self-supporting disks were measured at the 12-BM-B at W L III edge and 10ID at Mo K edge of Advanced Photo Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory. The X-ray absorption near edge structures (XANES) presented are transmission data and are average of at least two data sets from the same sample that were processed using standard pre-edge background subtraction and edge step normalization procedures using ATHENA program. Metal content was estimated by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis conducted on a Perkin Elmer emission spectrometer. Each 10mg sample of vacuum-dried material was dissolved in 5ml of boiling aqua fortis solution. A 1ml of hydrofluoric acid was added to dissolve the silica support (as for W-containing samples, 10ml of boiling 5% KOH was used instead of hydrofluoric acid) and then completely evaporated. The residue was acidified with concentrated HNO3 before dilution to 100ml with deionized water. Each solution was filtered through a 0.45μm polyethersulfone filter and then submitted for metal analysis. 2.4 Catalytic epoxidation Five milli-mole of cyclooctene and 5ml of solvent along with 50mg of catalyst (5mg for the pure complex) were added to a 100ml two-neck flask equipped with a stirrer and a reflux condenser. The mixture was heated to 70°C and then 5mmol of oxidant was injected into the solution to start the reaction. After the reaction was finished, the catalyst was filtered, washed and dried at 100°C overnight and reused directly without further purification. The liquid organic products were quantified by using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-8A) equipped with a flame detector and an HP-5 capillary column and confirmed by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural, morphological and textural properties The powder XRD patterns of pure siliceous SBA-15 and its modified ones are depicted in Fig. 1A. The SBA-15 sample showed three peaks, indexed as the (100), (110) and (200) diffraction peaks, associated with the typical inplane hexagonal symmetry of the SBA-15 material (Fig. 1Aa) [25]. For the hybrid materials, the relative intensities of the prominent diffraction peak (100) decreased somewhat after the introduction of chelate ligands or metal complexes. However, the main reflections of the XRD pattern can still be observed. According to the related literature [26], the intensity reduction may be mainly due to contrast matching between the silicate framework and organic moieties which are located inside the channels of SBA-15. However, as for ZnIIT-10% (Fig. 1Ab), MoO 2 VI G-10% (Fig. 1Ag) and WO2 VIG-10% (Fig. 1Ah), the (100) diffractions slightly shift to higher 2θ values, indicating a contraction of the unit cell. TEM images of representative MoO2 VIT-10% provide a direct visualization of well-ordered hexagonal arrays of 1D mesoporous channels particularly along the direction of the pore axis or in the direction perpendicular to the pore axis (Fig. 1Ca and b). This result is in good agreement with the conclusion drawn from the XRD patterns and confirms that characteristic pore dimensions and channel structures of the support materials remain intact after the introduction of metal complexes to the support and after being recycled (see Fig. 1Cc and d). SEM images of ZnIIT-10%, T-10% and MoO2 VIT-10% show rod-like domains aggregated to quasi-wheatlike macrostructure (Fig. 1De–g), similar to that of parent SBA-15 (not shown), indicating the preservation of surface morphology during the acid extraction process and metal complex incorporation. However, this quasi-wheatlike macrostructure was transformed to shorter rod-like domains once recycled (Fig. 1Dh). The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of SBA-15 and the hybrid materials are shown in Fig. 1B. Obviously, the hybrid materials maintain the characteristics of type IV isotherms with a sharp inflection due to the capillary condensation in the uniform mesopore channels and a H1 type hysteresis loop, and show a uniform pore size distribution in the mesoporous region, suggesting that the channels of the modified SBA-15 remain accessible. The inflections at relative pressures above 0.9 can be ascribed to the pores formed in the interstices of the particles [27,28]. As shown in Table 1 , the pore diameter decreased from 6.57nm for ZnIIT-10% to 5.50nm for MoO2 VIT-10% and to 5.42nm for WO2 VIT-10%. Compared with ZnIIT-10% and T-10%, a pronounced decrease of the BET surface area and the pore volume along with an increase of the wall thickness occurred for MoO2 VIT-10% and WO2 VIT-10% due to the introduction of metal complexes into the internal surfaces of the mesoporous materials. Similar trend has also been observed by comparative study of MoO2 VIT-5%, MoO2 VIT-10% and MoO2 VIT-15%. As illustrated in Table 1, the BET surface areas decrease from 588m2 g−1 for MoO2 VIT-5% to 277m2 g−1 for MoO2 VIT-15%, and correspondingly the pore volume decrease as well, indicating that MoVI compounds with different amount have been introduced into the inside channels of SBA-15 materials. 3.2 FT-IR and 29Si MAS NMR studies IR spectra of various samples are depicted in Fig. S7. It is evident that the framework vibrations of SBA-15 dominate the spectra below 1200cm−1 for all silica based materials. The bands at 1088, 956, 802 and 456cm−1 are attributed to SiOSi and SiOH vibrations [29]. No shift is observed upon introduction of chelate ligands and metal complexes, further substantiating that the SBA-15 framework remains unchanged. In spite of this, newly present CO, CN and aromatic ring vibrations are present at 1371, 1409, 1461 and 1505cm−1 for all ligand modified SBA-15 materials and pure metal complexes [30]. However, the hybrid materials show less and weaker bands in the range of 1560–1300cm−1, due to the strong IR absorbance of the siliceous materials. Moreover, the bands at 2857, 2922, and 2963cm−1 present in the spectra of the hybrid materials, are attributed to ν(CH2) of the propyl arm of the ligand [31]. Fig. 2A depicts 29Si MAS NMR spectra of pure siliceous SBA-15 and hybrid materials. For parent SBA-15, three resonance peaks at −110, −102 and −90ppm are observed, which should be ascribed to Q4 [Si(OSi)4], Q3 [Si(OSi)3OH] and Q2 [Si(OSi)2(OH)2] species. Additional resonance peaks at −63.5 to −66.9 and −55.0 to −58.0ppm are observed for ZnIIT-10%, MoO2 VIT-10% and MoO2 VIG-10%, which should be assigned to T3 [RSi(OSi)3] and T2 [RSi(OSi)2(OH)] sites [32], indicating that organic groups have been immobilized onto the mesoporous walls. 3.3 Thermogravimetric analysis Quantification of weight loss at various steps is possible because of nonoverlapping. The TG/DSC curves of various samples are shown in Fig. 2B. It is evident that pure [ZnII(1C)2]·H2O shows different TG/DSC characteristics from hybrid materials. As illustrated in Fig. 2Ba, [ZnII(1C)2]·H2O shows three step weight loss at temperatures ranged from 30 to 800°C. Below 150°C, weight loss of 3.5% can be ascribed to desorption of lattice water [33]. In the temperature range of 150–540°C, exothermic peaks at 331.4 and 467.6°C are observed and accompanied by a weight loss of 29.1%, ascribed to the decomposition of 8-quinolinol [34]. The stability of the final residues at ca. 750°C suggests the formation of Zn-C complex and charcoal. The remaining weight ratio ca. 63.0% is consistent with that of zinc and carbon (65.0%) calculated from the formula (C10H7NOCl)2Zn·H2O. As for the hybrid materials, the TG curve shows a two-step weight loss. Weight loss below 250°C is due to the physically adsorbed water and solvent inside the pores. The following weight loss of 8.0% in the range of 250–600°C for ZnIIT-10% (Fig. 2Bb), ascribed to the combustion of 8-quinolinol, corresponds to 0.51mmol/g of ligand. Similarly, T-10% (Fig. 2Bc), MoO2 VIT-10% (Fig. 2Bd) and MoO2 VIG-10% (Fig. 2Be) show ca. 8.8, 8.7 and 8.3% weight loss in this range, respectively, suggesting that the 8-quinolinol remain intact upon ZnII removal and reloading with MoVI. 3.4 Difference analysis Two methods for covalent attachment of 1P onto the SBA-15 silica were investigated: random grafting and metal-templating to create materials G and T, respectively (Scheme 1). Grafting was involved in the random attachment of 1p to the support surface to form an anticipated uncorrelated distribution of covalently attached ligands, 1. Metalation of this material with 0.5equiv. of Mo or W per 1 in CHCl3 gave MO2 VIG (M=Mo or W). The metal uptake by randomly grafted materials, at various 1 loadings yielded materials with less predictable ligand to metal ratios (less than 2:1, see Table 2 ). Such ratios are consistent with a distribution of bis-1 and mono-1 ligated metals. By contrast, the metal-template/metal-exchange procedure was developed to create bis(8-quinolinol) metal coordination sites on the SBA-15 surface. The metal template was a stable 2:1 complex of 5-(3-(trimethoxylsilyl)propylthio)methyl-8-quinolinol with ZnII, [Zn(1P)2], and was initially formed in solution and subsequently attached to the silica to give ZnIIT. Removal of zinc gave T, with an anticipated correlated distribution of pairs of covalently attached ligands. The metal uptake by the templated materials at various 1 loadings consistently yielded ca. 2:1 ratio of 1M−1 (Table 2), suggesting that the templating method created greater site isolation, allowing for a greater homogeneity of MoVI and WVI complexes. UV–vis spectra of templated MoVI and WVI complexes are shown in Fig. S8. Intense n–π*, π–π* ligand charge transfer bands in the range of 300–350nm and 230–280nm are present [31], much more similar to those of MoO2 VIN and WO2 VIN as compared to randomly grafted analogues, indicating that templated MoVI and WVI compounds retain solution-like bis(8-quinolinol) metal coordination spheres. Varied information at atomic scale is obtained by comparative study of pair distribution function (PDF) of MoO2 VIT-10% and MoO2 VIG-10%. As illustrated in Fig. 3A, peaks at ca. 1.6 and 2.6Ǻ confirm the expected retention of basic SiO4 tetrahedral building blocks with no Si-O bond breakage for both samples [35]. However, the distinct peaks ranged from 3 to 6Ǻ, and the different oscillations beyond 6.0Ǻ suggest that the local structure of MoVI compounds is different. On the other hand, the recycled MoO2 VIT-10% displays nearly the same PDF characteristic as the fresh MoO2 VIT-10%, indicating that MoVI complex remains intact after recyclability. Compared to PDF measurement, X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) is element specific for exploration of short-range structure around 1–3Ǻ. XAFS is required in this study, since MoVI and WVI cores are spectroscopically silent for both UV–vis and ESR measurements due to their empty d orbitals. Both XANES and EXAFS were measured to investigate the electronic environment and coordination structures for MoO2 VIT-10% and MoO2 VIG-10%. As illustrated in Fig. 3B, all XANES spectra exhibit a relatively broad edge, as expected for the short core-hole lifetime of Mo K-edge. MoO2 VIG-10% shows a weak transition at 20,005.3eV, while MoO2 VIT-10% shows additional pre-edge feature at 19,997.0eV, assigned to 1s→4d transition, which is formally dipole-forbidden and weakly quadrupole-allowed but gains intensity in a non-centrosymmetric molybdenum center by admixture of oxygen p-orbitals [36]. MoO2 VIT-10% and MoO2 VIG-10% also show difference in EXAFS region and in k-space (Fig. 3C): MoO2 VIG-10% shows clear oscillations at higher k region (k >12Å−1), indicating the dominance of higher Z backscatters, which would be Cl and/or Mo (see Scheme 1). The radial distribution function (RDF) shows well-resolved peaks ranged from 1 to 4Ǻ. Low-amplitude scattering at around 1.7Ǻ due to MoO interactions (Fig. 3D), and an increased amplitude at 2.5Ǻ due to MoO or MoN backscattering are observed for both samples [37]. However, the RDF peak intensity for MoO2 VIG-10% is more intense, suggesting larger coordination number, though the fitted results cannot be realized due to the absence of proper model. On the other hand, spent MoO2 VIT-10% shows quite similar XANES and EXAFS characteristics to the fresh MoO2 VIT-10%, indicating that the electronic environment and coordination structure of MoVI complexes remains intact after recyclability. 3.5 Catalytic properties Table 3 summarizes the catalytic results for the epoxidation of cyclooctene over various catalysts. As expected, all catalysts are active for the epoxidation of cyclooctene with nearly 100% of selectivity to epoxycyclooctane. Considering that the residue zinc complex may play a role, the templated complex, ZnIIT-10%, was also carried out for epoxidation experiments. It turns out that only 2.6% of cyclooctene was converted after 8h. By contrast, the neat metal complexes, MoO2 VIN, plus the corresponding supported analogues, MoO2 VIT-10% and MoO2 VIG-10%, exhibit high activity, indicating the active sites are MoVI complexes, not ZnII species. Solvents and oxidants affect the catalytic performance significantly. In our experiment, representative MoO2 VIT-10% was tested using TBHP or H2O2 as the oxidant, combined with CHCl3 or CH3CN as the solvent. As illustrated in Table 3, MoO2 VIT-10% behaves better when using H2O2 as the oxidant and CH3CN as the solvent (87.8%, TOF 48.3h−1) than when using TBHP/CH3CN and H2O2/CHCl3 combinations, and the best performance (conversion 92.4%, TOF 54.0h−1) was displayed when using TBHP as the oxidant and CHCl3 as the solvent (Entries 1–4), which agrees with the literature findings [12,26]. Under optimized reaction conditions, MoO2 VIG-10% and MoO2 VIT-10% are more active than MoO2 VIN, suggesting that heterogenization of MoVI complexes probably isolated the neat complexes and prevented their dimerization. On the other hand, MoO2 VIT-10% behaves better than MoO2 VIG-10%, as verified by both higher conversion and TOF value. The recycling experiments were also carried out for MoO2 VIT-10% and MoO2 VIG-10% (Fig. 4 , inset). MoO2 VIT-10% shows excellent recyclability, and the conversion of cyclooctene still remains at around 80% after five cycles; while MoO2 VIG-10% displays a gradual decrease in activity when recycled. The templated MoVI complex acts mainly as a heterogeneous catalyst but there remains a need for rigorous proof of heterogeneity. Hence, leaching tests for MoO2 VIT-10% and MoO2 VIG-10% catalysts were performed to verify the heterogeneity of these catalytic processes. We filtered the catalyst at the reaction temperature (70°C), e.g., the MoO2 VIT-10% after 1.5h (60.9% cyclooctene conversion). At this time, half the volume was filtered and the resulting clear solution was allowed to react. The percentage of leaching was estimated by comparing the time-conversion plot of the twin reactions with and without solid. It is found that cyclooctene converted slowly without catalyst (Fig. 4) and this trend is almost parallel to the blank experiment (not shown). The filtrate neither shows any activity nor presents Mo species in the filtrate. However, as for MoO2 VIG-10%, it was found that after the hot filtration, the mother liquor reacted further at roughly the same rate as that observed when the catalyst was not filtered, which leads to the inevitable conclusion that most of the observed activity can be attributed to homogeneous MoVI species leached from the support. According to the literature [38], we suppose that the remarkable leaching occurred for MoO2 VIG-10% can be attributed to the change of the instable coordinate environment of the active sites during the reaction. Hence the greater efficiency for MoO2 VIT-10% emphasizes the benefits of site-isolated bis-1 coordination sphere, and the site homogeneity of templated catalysts. Catalytic properties of randomly grafted and templated MoVI and WVI catalysts with different metal loadings are also investigated. As illustrated in Table 3, the cyclooctene conversion was improved accompanied by the increased Mo or W content. Take templated WVI catalysts for example, cyclooctene conversion was improved from 75.3 to 96.4% when W content was elevated from 0.0349 to 0.1240mmolg−1, while the TOF values decreased meanwhile. Similar to MoVI catalyst, templated WVI catalyst is also more active than randomly grafted WVI catalyst. 4 Conclusions The incorporation of MoVI and WVI centers into an immobilized, site-isolated, bis(8-quinolinol) coordination sphere on SBA-15 was successful achieved by a newly developed metal-template/metal-exchange method to control the distribution of covalently attached independent ligands at various loadings. These templated catalysts as well as randomly grafted ones are fully characterized by XRD, TEM, SEM, N2 adsorption/desorption, TG/DSC, FT-IR and 29Si MAS NMR techniques, and the composition and local structure difference was verified by CHN elemental analysis, ICP-AES, UV–vis, PDF and XAFS measurements. These imprinted MoVI and WVI catalysts are more efficient than either their homogeneous or randomly grafted analogues. Furthermore, the templated MoVI catalyst is significantly stable and can be recycled many times. The correlated distribution of isolated bis(8-quinolinol) coordination sphere is proposed to be critical to enhance the reactivity of catalysts with different loadings. coredata.dc:description: A metal-template/metal-exchange method was used to imprint covalently attached bis(8-quinolinolato)dioxomolybdenum(VI) and dioxotungsten(VI) complexes onto large surface-area, mesoporous SBA-15 silica to obtain discrete MoO2 VIT and WO2 VIT catalysts bearing different metal loadings, respectively. Homogeneous counterparts, MoO2 VIN and WO2 VIN, as well as randomly ligand-grafted heterogeneous analogues, MoO2 VIG and WO2 VIG, were also prepared for comparison. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS), pair distribution function (PDF) and UV–vis data demonstrate that MoO2 VIT and WO2 VIT adopt a more solution-like bis(8-quinolinol) coordination environment than MoO2 VIG and WO2 VIG, respectively. Correspondingly, the templated MoVI and WVI catalysts show superior performances to their randomly grafted counterparts and neat analogues in the epoxidation of cyclooctene. It is found that the representative MoO2 VIT-10% catalyst can be recycled up to five times without significant loss of reactivity, and heterogeneity test confirms the high stability of MoO2 VIT-10% catalyst against leaching of active species into solution. The homogeneity of the discrete bis(8-quinolinol) metal spheres templated on SBA-15 should be responsible for the superior performances.
